Problem:
Consider a complex function governed by \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\(i\\) is the imaginary unit, and the dynamical system is characterized by \\( \\dot{z} = Pz + Q \\) with constant matrices P and Q. We explore how the system behaves with respect to the transformation \\( h(z) = e^{Mt}z \\) where M is another constant matrix.

If, at some time \\( t_1 \\), an intervention via another transformation \\( k(z) = e^{Nt}z \\) (where N is a constant matrix) is applied, would the outcome at \\( z(T) \\) solely depend on the matrix P?
Explanation: Due to the properties of linear transformations and matrix exponentiation, different combinations of M and N along with different starting vectors could yield the same outcome at \\( z(T) \\). Thus, there is inherent ambiguity in the exact transformation paths taken to reach \\( z(T) \\).
